lessons.title: What is CSS and How It Works
lessons.content: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation and visual styling of HTML documents. It controls colors, fonts, layouts, spacing, and animations. CSS works by selecting HTML elements and applying style rules to them. The 'cascading' nature means styles can be inherited and overridden based on specificity and source order.

examples.description: Basic CSS syntax showing how to style heading and paragraph elements

quiz.question: What does CSS stand for?
quiz.explanation: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. The 'cascading' refers to how styles are applied in a hierarchical manner with inheritance and specificity rules.

quiz.question: What is the main purpose of CSS?
options: To style and layout web pages
quiz.answer: To style and layout web pages
quiz.explanation: CSS is used to control the visual presentation of HTML documents, including colors, fonts, spacing, and layouts.

lessons.challenge: Create a simple CSS rule that changes the color of all paragraphs to navy blue and sets their font size to 16px.
tips: CSS separates content (HTML) from presentation (styling)
One CSS file can style multiple HTML pages
CSS makes websites consistent and easier to maintain
Modern CSS includes powerful features like Grid, Flexbox, and animations

lessons.title: Types of CSS (Inline, Internal, External)
lessons.content: There are three ways to add CSS to HTML: Inline CSS (using the style attribute directly on elements), Internal CSS (using <style> tags in the HTML document's head), and External CSS (linking separate .css files). External CSS is the most recommended approach as it promotes reusability, maintainability, and separation of concerns.

examples.code: Red text
examples.description: Three different methods of applying CSS to HTML

quiz.question: Which type of CSS has the highest specificity?
quiz.hint: Think about which one is closest to the element
quiz.explanation: Inline CSS has the highest specificity because it's applied directly to the element, overriding both internal and external styles (unless !important is used).

quiz.question: Which method is best for styling multiple pages?
quiz.explanation: External CSS is best for multiple pages because one stylesheet can be linked to many HTML files, promoting consistency and easier maintenance.

lessons.challenge: Create an HTML page with all three types of CSS: inline style on one element, internal styles in the head, and a link to an external stylesheet.
tips: Use external CSS for production websites
Inline CSS is useful for quick tests or email templates
Internal CSS can be good for single-page sites or unique page styles
External CSS files are cached by browsers, improving performance

lessons.title: CSS Syntax and Selectors Overview
lessons.content: CSS syntax consists of a selector and a declaration block. The selector targets HTML elements, and the declaration block contains property-value pairs enclosed in curly braces. Each declaration includes a property name, a colon, a value, and ends with a semicolon. Selectors can target elements by tag name, class, ID, attributes, and more.

examples.description: CSS syntax structure with selector and declaration blocks

quiz.question: What punctuation separates a CSS property from its value?
quiz.hint: Look at how color: blue is written
quiz.explanation: A colon (:) separates the property name from its value, while a semicolon (;) ends each declaration.

quiz.question: What surrounds CSS declarations?
quiz.explanation: CSS declarations are enclosed in curly braces { } after the selector.

lessons.challenge: Write a CSS rule with proper syntax that styles an element with three different properties: color, font-size, and margin.
tips: Always end declarations with semicolons to avoid errors
CSS is case-insensitive for properties but case-sensitive for class/ID names
Proper indentation makes CSS more readable
Comments in CSS use /* comment */ syntax

lessons.title: Applying CSS to HTML
lessons.content: To apply CSS to HTML, you can use the <link> element in the HTML head section to connect external stylesheets, use <style> tags for internal CSS, or add the style attribute for inline CSS. The link element uses the rel='stylesheet' attribute and href to specify the CSS file path. Modern best practice is to place external stylesheet links in the head for optimal loading.

examples.code: Hello CSS!
examples.description: Complete example showing all three methods of applying CSS to HTML

quiz.question: Where should external CSS links be placed?
quiz.hint: Think about when styles should load
quiz.explanation: External CSS links should be in the <head> section so styles load before the page content renders, preventing unstyled content flash.

quiz.question: What attribute connects an external CSS file?
quiz.explanation: The href attribute in the <link> element specifies the path to the external CSS file.

lessons.challenge: Create an HTML file that links to an external CSS file named 'main.css' and verify the connection by adding a style rule in the CSS file.
tips: Use relative paths for CSS files in the same project
Multiple stylesheets can be linked to one HTML file
The order of stylesheets matters - later ones can override earlier ones
Check browser DevTools Network tab if styles don't load

lessons.title: Comments in CSS
lessons.content: CSS comments are created using /* comment text */ syntax and can span multiple lines. Comments are ignored by browsers and are used to document code, explain complex styling, temporarily disable rules, or organize stylesheets into sections. Good commenting practices make CSS more maintainable and easier for teams to work with.

examples.description: Various uses of CSS comments for documentation and organization

quiz.question: What is the correct syntax for CSS comments?
quiz.hint: Different from HTML and JavaScript comments
quiz.explanation: CSS uses /* */ for comments, which can span multiple lines. This is different from HTML <!-- --> and JavaScript // comments.

quiz.question: Can CSS comments span multiple lines?
quiz.explanation: CSS comments using /* */ can span multiple lines, making them useful for longer explanations and documentation.

lessons.challenge: Create a CSS file with organized sections using comments. Include a header section, body section, and footer section with descriptive comments for each.
tips: Use comments to create visual separators between sections
Comment out code instead of deleting it when testing
Add TODOs in comments for future improvements
Document why you chose certain values, not just what they do
Avoid over-commenting obvious code

lessons.title: Understanding Colors (Named, HEX, RGB, HSL)
lessons.content: CSS supports multiple color formats: named colors (red, blue), hexadecimal (#FF0000), RGB (rgb(255, 0, 0)), RGBA with transparency (rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)), HSL (hue, saturation, lightness), and HSLA. HEX is compact, RGB is intuitive, and HSL is great for color variations. Modern CSS also supports color functions and the newer color() function.

examples.description: Different color format syntaxes in CSS

quiz.question: Which color format allows transparency?
quiz.explanation: RGBA and HSLA include an alpha channel (the 'A') that controls transparency, with values from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).

quiz.question: What does the # symbol indicate in CSS?
quiz.hint: It has two different uses depending on context
quiz.explanation: The # symbol indicates a hexadecimal color when followed by 3 or 6 hex digits (like #FF0000), and an ID selector when followed by text (like #header).

lessons.challenge: Create a color palette using all four color formats. Style four different elements using named, HEX, RGB, and HSL colors respectively.
tips: Use HEX for solid colors - it's compact and widely supported
Use RGBA/HSLA when you need transparency
HSL is intuitive for creating color variations (lighter/darker)
Browser DevTools let you convert between color formats
Consider color accessibility and contrast ratios

lessons.title: CSS Units (px, %, em, rem, vh, vw)
lessons.content: CSS units are divided into absolute (px, pt, cm) and relative (%, em, rem, vh, vw) units. Pixels (px) are fixed, percentages (%) are relative to parent elements, em is relative to the parent font-size, rem is relative to root font-size, and vh/vw are relative to viewport height/width. Relative units are crucial for responsive design and accessibility.

examples.description: Different CSS units and their use cases

quiz.question: Which unit is relative to the root element's font size?
quiz.explanation: rem (root em) is relative to the root element's (html) font-size, making it predictable and great for consistent sizing.

quiz.question: What does 100vh represent?
quiz.explanation: 100vh equals 100% of the viewport height (the visible browser window), making it perfect for full-screen sections.

lessons.challenge: Create a layout using different units: a container with a max-width in pixels, child elements with percentage widths, text sized in rem, and a hero section using viewport units.
tips: Use rem for font sizes for better accessibility
Use % for flexible layouts that adapt to parents
Prefer relative units over pixels for responsive design
vh and vw are great for full-screen sections
Avoid using em for multiple nested elements (compounds)
Set a base font-size on html element when using rem

lessons.title: Element, Class, and ID Selectors
lessons.content: Element selectors target HTML tags (p, div, h1), class selectors use a period prefix (.classname) and can be applied to multiple elements, and ID selectors use a hash prefix (#idname) for unique elements. Classes are reusable and preferred for styling, while IDs should be unique per page and are often used for JavaScript or page anchors.

examples.description: Three fundamental selector types in CSS

quiz.question: Which selector has the highest specificity?
quiz.explanation: ID selectors have higher specificity than class selectors, which have higher specificity than element selectors. Specificity hierarchy: inline styles > IDs > classes > elements.

quiz.question: Can a class be used on multiple elements?
quiz.hint: Classes are meant to be reusable
quiz.explanation: Classes are designed to be reusable across multiple elements, making them ideal for applying consistent styling throughout a website.

lessons.challenge: Create an HTML page with three paragraphs: one styled with an element selector, one with a class, and one with an ID. Notice how the specificity affects the styling.
tips: Prefer classes over IDs for styling - they're more reusable
Use meaningful class names that describe purpose, not appearance
IDs should be unique - only one per page
Elements can have multiple classes: class='btn primary large'
Avoid over-relying on IDs as they increase specificity issues

lessons.title: Universal and Grouping Selectors
lessons.content: The universal selector (*) targets all elements on a page and is commonly used for CSS resets or applying global styles. Grouping selectors let you apply the same styles to multiple selectors by separating them with commas, reducing code duplication and improving maintainability.

examples.description: Universal and grouping selector examples

quiz.question: What does the * selector target?
quiz.explanation: The universal selector (*) targets every single element on the page, making it useful for global resets or base styles.

quiz.question: How do you separate selectors in a grouping?
quiz.explanation: Commas separate selectors in a group, allowing you to apply the same styles to multiple selectors in one rule.

lessons.challenge: Create a CSS reset using the universal selector, then group all heading tags (h1-h6) to apply a common font family and color.
tips: Use * selector sparingly - it can impact performance on large pages
Common use for * is setting box-sizing: border-box globally
Grouping reduces code repetition and makes updates easier
Format grouped selectors with each on its own line for readability
Don't overuse grouping - sometimes specificity matters

lessons.title: Descendant, Child, and Sibling Selectors
lessons.content: Combinators define relationships between selectors. Descendant selector (space) targets nested elements at any level, child selector (>) targets direct children only, adjacent sibling (+) targets the immediately following sibling, and general sibling (~) targets all following siblings. These enable precise targeting based on HTML structure.

examples.description: Four types of combinator selectors showing element relationships

quiz.question: Which selector targets only direct children?
quiz.explanation: The child selector (>) targets only direct children, not deeper descendants, providing more specific control.

quiz.question: What's the difference between + and ~ selectors?
options: + targets immediate next sibling, ~ targets all following siblings
+ is for children, ~ is for parents
quiz.answer: + targets immediate next sibling, ~ targets all following siblings
quiz.hint: Think about how many siblings are targeted
quiz.explanation: The adjacent sibling selector (+) targets only the immediately following sibling, while the general sibling selector (~) targets all following siblings.

lessons.challenge: Create HTML with nested elements and use all four combinators: descendant, child, adjacent sibling, and general sibling selectors to style different relationships.
tips: Use child selector (>) instead of descendant when possible for better performance
Sibling selectors are great for styling elements that follow headings
Combinators don't work backwards - you can't select previous siblings
Keep selector chains short (2-3 levels) for maintainability
Use DevTools to visualize which elements your combinators select

lessons.title: Attribute Selectors
lessons.content: Attribute selectors target elements based on their attributes and values. Basic syntax is [attribute], and variations include [attr=value] (exact match), [attr^=value] (starts with), [attr$=value] (ends with), [attr*=value] (contains), and [attr~=value] (word match). These are powerful for styling links, inputs, and elements with data attributes.

examples.description: Various attribute selector patterns for targeting elements

quiz.question: Which attribute selector checks if value contains a substring?
quiz.explanation: [attr*=value] matches elements where the attribute contains the specified value anywhere within it.

quiz.question: What does [href^='https'] select?
quiz.explanation: The ^= operator selects elements where the attribute value starts with the specified string, in this case 'https'.

lessons.challenge: Create a form with different input types and use attribute selectors to style text inputs differently from email inputs, and style all buttons that have a data-size attribute.
tips: Use attribute selectors to style different input types uniquely
Great for styling external vs internal links
Data attributes are perfect for JavaScript hooks and CSS styling
Attribute selectors are case-sensitive by default
Add [i] flag for case-insensitive matching: [attr=value i]
Combine with other selectors: a[href^='http'][target='_blank']

lessons.title: Pseudo-classes (like :hover, :focus, :active)
lessons.content: Pseudo-classes select elements based on their state or position. Common interactive pseudo-classes include :hover (mouse over), :focus (element focused), :active (being clicked), :visited (visited links). Structural pseudo-classes include :first-child, :last-child, :nth-child(), :not(). These enable dynamic styling without JavaScript.

examples.description: Various pseudo-classes for different states and positions

quiz.question: Which pseudo-class is triggered when hovering over an element?
quiz.explanation: :hover applies styles when the mouse pointer is over an element, commonly used for interactive effects.

quiz.question: What does :nth-child(even) select?
quiz.explanation: :nth-child(even) selects all children at even positions (2nd, 4th, 6th, etc.), useful for alternating row colors.

lessons.challenge: Create a navigation menu that changes color on hover, a form with focus styles for inputs, and a table with alternating row colors using :nth-child.
tips: Always style :focus for keyboard accessibility
Use :hover, :focus, and :active together for complete interactivity
:nth-child() counts all siblings, :nth-of-type() counts specific elements
Combine pseudo-classes: a:hover:not(.active)
:focus-visible shows focus only for keyboard navigation
Test interactive states on both mouse and keyboard users

lessons.title: Pseudo-elements (::before, ::after)
lessons.content: Pseudo-elements create virtual elements in the DOM using ::before and ::after, which insert content before or after an element's actual content. They require the content property and act as inline elements by default. Pseudo-elements are perfect for decorative elements, icons, clearfix, and creative effects without adding HTML markup.

examples.description: Pseudo-elements for adding decorative content and effects

quiz.question: Which property is required for ::before and ::after?
quiz.hint: Without this, they won't show at all
quiz.explanation: The content property is mandatory for ::before and ::after pseudo-elements, even if it's just an empty string content: ''.

quiz.question: How many colons should pseudo-elements use?
quiz.explanation: Modern CSS uses double colons (::) for pseudo-elements to distinguish them from pseudo-classes (:), though single colon still works for backwards compatibility.

lessons.challenge: Create a blockquote with decorative quotation marks using ::before and ::after, and a button that shows an arrow icon using a pseudo-element.
tips: Pseudo-elements don't work on replaced elements (img, input, etc.)
content property can use attr() to display attribute values
Set display: block or position: absolute for better control
Use for decorative content only - not for meaningful content
Pseudo-elements can't be selected by users or accessed by screen readers
Great for icons, decorative shapes, and clearfix techniques

lessons.title: Combining Multiple Selectors
lessons.content: Complex selectors combine multiple selector types, combinators, pseudo-classes, and pseudo-elements to target specific elements precisely. You can chain classes (.btn.primary), combine element with class (div.container), use multiple combinators (div > ul li), and mix pseudo-classes with other selectors. Understanding selector specificity and order is crucial for managing cascading styles.

examples.description: Complex selector combinations for precise targeting

quiz.question: What does .btn.primary select?
options: Elements with both btn AND primary classes
Elements with btn OR primary class
quiz.answer: Elements with both btn AND primary classes
quiz.hint: No space means both classes required
quiz.explanation: When classes are chained without spaces, the element must have all specified classes. <div class='btn primary'> would match.

quiz.question: Which has higher specificity: .header or div.header?
quiz.explanation: div.header has higher specificity (1 element + 1 class) compared to .header (1 class only). Specificity: 0-1-1 vs 0-1-0.

lessons.challenge: Create a navigation menu where only the first link in each list item has a special icon (using ::before), and all links except the last one have a separator, using combined selectors.
tips: No space between selectors means AND condition
Space between selectors means descendant relationship
Calculate specificity: inline=1000, IDs=100, classes/attrs/pseudo-classes=10, elements=1
More specific selectors override less specific ones
Avoid overly complex selectors - keep them readable
Use browser DevTools to see which rules apply and why

lessons.title: Font Properties (font-family, font-size, weight, style)
lessons.content: Font properties control typography appearance. font-family specifies typeface with fallbacks, font-size sets text size, font-weight controls thickness (normal, bold, 100-900), and font-style adds italic or oblique. The font shorthand combines multiple properties. Always include web-safe fallback fonts and consider system font stacks for performance.

examples.description: Comprehensive font property examples

quiz.question: Why should font-family have multiple values?
options: For fallback if first font unavailable
quiz.answer: For fallback if first font unavailable
quiz.hint: Think about what happens if a font isn't installed
quiz.explanation: Multiple font values provide fallbacks if the preferred font isn't available on the user's system, ensuring consistent rendering.

quiz.question: What numeric values can font-weight accept?
quiz.explanation: font-weight accepts numeric values from 100 (thinnest) to 900 (boldest) in increments of 100. 400 is normal, 700 is bold.

lessons.challenge: Create a typography system with three heading levels using different font sizes, weights, and a body text style. Include a system font stack for optimal performance.
tips: Always end font-family list with generic family (serif, sans-serif, monospace)
Use rem or em for font-size to support user preferences
font-weight: 400 = normal, 700 = bold
Not all fonts support all weight values
Use Variable Fonts for more weight options with one file
System fonts load instantly - no web requests needed

lessons.title: Line Height, Letter Spacing, and Word Spacing
lessons.content: These properties control text spacing and readability. line-height sets vertical space between lines (unitless values recommended), letter-spacing adjusts space between characters (tracking), and word-spacing controls space between words. Proper spacing dramatically improves readability, especially for body text. Optimal line-height for body text is typically 1.5-1.6.

examples.description: Text spacing properties for improved readability

quiz.question: What's the recommended line-height for body text?
quiz.hint: Not too tight, not too loose
quiz.explanation: A line-height of 1.5-1.6 provides optimal readability for body text by giving lines enough breathing room without being too spaced out.

quiz.question: Why use unitless values for line-height?
quiz.explanation: Unitless line-height values are multipliers of the element's font-size, making them inherit properly and scale correctly with font size changes.

lessons.challenge: Create a blog post layout with different line-heights for headings (1.2) and body text (1.6), and experiment with letter-spacing on a heading to see the visual impact.
tips: Use unitless line-height values (1.5 not 1.5em) for proper inheritance
Headings need tighter line-height (1.1-1.3) than body text
Increase letter-spacing for uppercase text for better readability
Negative letter-spacing can make large text feel tighter
Don't overdo word-spacing - it can reduce readability
Test readability with actual content, not Lorem Ipsum

lessons.title: Text Alignment, Decoration, and Transformation
lessons.content: Text styling properties control appearance and layout. text-align positions text (left, right, center, justify), text-decoration adds lines (underline, line-through, overline), text-transform changes case (uppercase, lowercase, capitalize), text-indent indents first line, and text-shadow adds shadows. These properties enhance visual hierarchy and emphasis.

examples.description: Text styling properties for visual effects

quiz.question: Which text-align value stretches text to fill the line?
quiz.explanation: text-align: justify stretches text by adjusting spacing so both left and right edges align, commonly seen in newspapers and books.

quiz.question: How many values does text-shadow accept?
quiz.explanation: text-shadow accepts: horizontal offset, vertical offset, blur radius (optional), and color. Example: 2px 2px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.5)

lessons.challenge: Create a hero section with centered uppercase text, a glowing text-shadow effect, and a paragraph with justified alignment and first-line indent.
tips: Remove default underline from links: text-decoration: none
text-transform: uppercase looks better with increased letter-spacing
Use text-align: center sparingly - left-aligned text is more readable
justify can create awkward spacing - use carefully
text-shadow can reduce readability - keep it subtle
Multiple text shadows are applied front-to-back in declaration order

lessons.title: Working with Google Fonts
lessons.content: Google Fonts provides free, high-quality web fonts. To use them, add a link tag in HTML head or @import in CSS, then reference the font in font-family. You can select specific weights and styles to optimize loading. Consider using font-display: swap for better performance, and limit the number of fonts and weights to reduce page load time.

examples.description: Implementing Google Fonts in web projects

quiz.question: Which method is faster: link or @import for Google Fonts?
quiz.hint: Think about when fonts can start loading
quiz.explanation: Using <link> in HTML head allows fonts to start loading earlier, before CSS is parsed, resulting in faster font rendering.

quiz.question: What does font-display: swap do?
options: Shows fallback font first, swaps when custom font loads
quiz.answer: Shows fallback font first, swaps when custom font loads
quiz.explanation: font-display: swap shows fallback text immediately and swaps to the custom font when it loads, preventing invisible text during loading.

lessons.challenge: Add Google Fonts to a project using the link method. Choose two fonts: one for headings and one for body text. Select only the weights you need (e.g., 400, 700).
tips: Only load font weights you actually use to reduce file size
Combine multiple fonts in one request when possible
Use font-display: swap to prevent invisible text (FOIT)
Consider system fonts for better performance
Preconnect to Google Fonts: <link rel='preconnect' href='https://fonts.googleapis.com'>
Variable fonts offer all weights in one file
Test font loading on slow connections

lessons.title: Responsive Text (using relative units)
lessons.content: Responsive typography scales text across different screen sizes using relative units (rem, em, vw) and CSS clamp(). The clamp() function sets minimum, preferred, and maximum sizes in one declaration. Combining viewport units with rem creates fluid typography that adapts smoothly. This approach improves readability across devices without manual breakpoint adjustments.

examples.description: Responsive typography techniques using modern CSS

quiz.question: What does clamp(1rem, 2vw, 3rem) do?
options: Sets min 1rem, scales with viewport, max 3rem
quiz.answer: Sets min 1rem, scales with viewport, max 3rem
quiz.explanation: clamp(min, preferred, max) creates fluid sizing that scales between minimum and maximum values based on the preferred value (often viewport-based).

quiz.question: Why is rem preferred over px for responsive text?
quiz.explanation: rem units scale with the root font-size, respecting user browser preferences for larger/smaller text, crucial for accessibility.

lessons.challenge: Create a responsive heading system where h1 uses clamp() to scale between 1.5rem and 3rem based on viewport width, and body text uses rem units with a responsive base font-size.
tips: Set base font-size on html element for rem calculation
Use clamp() to avoid excessive text sizes on large screens
Combine vw with rem for smooth scaling: clamp(1rem, 2vw + 1rem, 3rem)
Test on actual devices - viewport units behave differently
Don't let text get too small on mobile (minimum 16px for body)
Adjust base font-size at breakpoints for finer control
Use rem for spacing too, not just font sizes

lessons.title: Background Color and Images
lessons.content: Background properties control element backgrounds. background-color sets solid colors, background-image adds images using url(). You can use multiple backgrounds by separating them with commas. The background shorthand combines color, image, position, size, repeat, and attachment. Linear and radial gradients are also background-image values.

examples.description: Background color and image techniques

quiz.question: How do you specify multiple background images?
quiz.explanation: Multiple backgrounds are listed with commas, and they layer from front to back in the order declared.

quiz.question: Which comes first in multiple backgrounds?
quiz.hint: Think of layering from front to back
quiz.explanation: In multiple backgrounds, the first image listed appears on top, with subsequent images layered behind.

lessons.challenge: Create a hero section with a background image, add a dark overlay using a gradient, and ensure the text remains readable. Use the background shorthand property.
tips: Always provide a background-color fallback before image
Optimize images for web - compress and use appropriate formats
Use WebP format for better compression with fallbacks
Multiple backgrounds layer front-to-back in declaration order
Gradients can act as overlays over images
Consider using object-fit for tags instead of backgrounds for content images

lessons.title: Background Repeat, Position, and Size
lessons.content: Control how backgrounds display with background-repeat (repeat, no-repeat, repeat-x, repeat-y), background-position (keywords, percentages, pixels), and background-size (cover, contain, specific dimensions). The cover value scales to fill the container, contain scales to fit within, and custom values allow precise control. These properties are essential for responsive background images.

examples.description: Background positioning and sizing properties

quiz.question: What does background-size: cover do?
quiz.hint: Think about covering the entire area
quiz.explanation: cover scales the image to completely fill the container while maintaining aspect ratio, potentially cropping parts of the image.

quiz.question: What's the difference between cover and contain?
options: cover fills container, contain fits inside
quiz.answer: cover fills container, contain fits inside
quiz.hint: One might crop, one shows everything
quiz.explanation: cover ensures the container is filled (may crop image), while contain ensures the entire image is visible (may leave empty space).

lessons.challenge: Create three different sections: one with a tiled pattern using repeat, one with a hero image using cover, and one with a logo using contain and center positioning.
tips: Use background-size: cover for hero sections and full-width images
Use contain when you need to see the entire image
Combine position and size: background: url() center/cover no-repeat
background-position: center keeps images centered when resizing
Test different screen sizes - cover may crop important parts
Use background-attachment: fixed for parallax effects

lessons.title: Gradient Backgrounds (linear & radial)
lessons.content: CSS gradients create smooth color transitions without images. linear-gradient() creates linear transitions, radial-gradient() creates circular patterns, and conic-gradient() creates angle-based gradients. Gradients can have multiple color stops, directions, and positions. They're treated as background-images and can be combined with other backgrounds for creative effects.

examples.description: Various gradient types and patterns

quiz.question: What's the default direction for linear-gradient?
quiz.explanation: Without specifying direction, linear-gradient defaults to 'to bottom', flowing from top to bottom.

quiz.question: Can you combine gradients with background images?
quiz.explanation: Gradients are background-image values, so they can be combined with images using comma-separated multiple backgrounds.

lessons.challenge: Create a modern UI with: a linear gradient button, a radial gradient background, and a section with a gradient overlay on top of a background image.
tips: Use gradients for modern, flat design aesthetics
Add transparency to create overlay effects: linear-gradient(rgba(0,0,0,0.5), rgba(0,0,0,0.8))
Use online gradient generators for complex patterns
Gradients can be animated with CSS transitions on background-position
repeating-linear-gradient is perfect for stripe patterns
Consider performance - complex gradients can impact rendering

lessons.title: Border Styles, Width, and Radius
lessons.content: Border properties add lines around elements. border-style defines appearance (solid, dashed, dotted, double), border-width sets thickness, border-color sets color, and border-radius creates rounded corners. The border shorthand combines width, style, and color. Individual sides can be targeted (border-top, border-right). Border-radius accepts up to 4 values for different corners.

examples.description: Border and border-radius styling options

quiz.question: What value creates a perfect circle with border-radius?
quiz.explanation: border-radius: 50% creates a perfect circle on square elements by rounding each corner halfway to the center.

quiz.question: What's the correct order in border shorthand?
quiz.explanation: While browsers accept any order, the conventional order is: border: width style color (e.g., border: 2px solid red).

lessons.challenge: Create four different styled boxes: one with solid borders, one with dashed borders, one with rounded corners, and one that's a perfect circle. Add a card with only a bottom border.
tips: border-style is required for borders to show
Use border-radius: 50% on squares to create circles
Individual corners: border-top-left-radius, border-top-right-radius, etc.
Can specify horizontal and vertical radius: border-radius: 50px / 25px
border: none removes borders completely
Use currentColor to match border color to text color

lessons.title: Outline and Box Shadows
lessons.content: Outlines and shadows add depth and focus indicators. outline is similar to border but doesn't affect layout and appears outside borders. box-shadow creates drop shadows with X-offset, Y-offset, blur, spread, and color. Multiple shadows can be applied. Outlines are crucial for accessibility (focus states), while shadows enhance visual depth and hierarchy.

examples.description: Outline and box-shadow for focus and depth

quiz.question: What's the difference between outline and border?

lessons.title: Creating Fancy Buttons with Hover Effects
lessons.content: Modern buttons combine colors, borders, shadows, transitions, and pseudo-classes to create engaging interactive elements. Use padding for size, border-radius for shape, background colors or gradients, box-shadow for depth, and transform on hover. Transitions smooth the state changes. Consider all states: default, hover, focus, active, and disabled.

quiz.explanation: The transition property smoothly animates changes between states (like hover), creating polished interactions.

quiz.hint: Think about specificity and typical use
quiz.explanation: While CSS specificity determines precedence, the conventional order is :hover, :focus, :active to ensure proper interaction styling.

lessons.title: Understanding Box Model (content, padding, border, margin)
lessons.content: The CSS box model describes how elements are rendered with four areas: content (actual content), padding (space inside border), border (line around padding), and margin (space outside border). Total element width = content width + padding + border + margin. Understanding the box model is fundamental to layout and spacing control in CSS.

examples.description: The CSS box model with all four components

quiz.question: What's the order of box model layers from inside out?
quiz.explanation: From inside out: content (the actual content), padding (space inside border), border (the edge), margin (space outside).

quiz.question: If an element has width: 200px, padding: 20px, border: 5px, what's the total width?
quiz.hint: Add padding and border on both sides
quiz.explanation: Total width = 200px (content) + 40px (padding both sides) + 10px (border both sides) = 250px.

lessons.challenge: Create three boxes with different padding, border, and margin values. Use browser DevTools to visualize the box model and see how each property affects the total size.
tips: Use DevTools to visualize the box model on any element
Padding creates space inside, margin creates space outside
Margins can collapse between adjacent elements
Background color fills content and padding areas, not margin
Border adds to the element's total size (unless box-sizing: border-box)
Negative margins pull elements closer or create overlaps

lessons.title: Width, Height, and Overflow
lessons.content: Width and height properties control element dimensions. They can use fixed values (px), percentages, or auto. max-width and min-width set constraints. The overflow property controls content that exceeds dimensions: visible (default), hidden (clips), scroll (adds scrollbars), auto (scrollbars when needed). Overflow-x and overflow-y control individual axes.

examples.description: Controlling dimensions and content overflow

quiz.question: What does overflow: auto do?
options: Shows scrollbar only when content overflows
quiz.answer: Shows scrollbar only when content overflows
quiz.explanation: overflow: auto adds scrollbars automatically only when content exceeds the container dimensions, unlike scroll which always shows scrollbars.

quiz.question: Why use max-width: 100% on images?
options: Prevents images from exceeding container width
quiz.answer: Prevents images from exceeding container width
quiz.explanation: max-width: 100% ensures images never exceed their container width, making them responsive while maintaining aspect ratio.

lessons.challenge: Create a fixed-height container with overflowing content and experiment with overflow values (visible, hidden, scroll, auto). Then create a responsive container with max-width constraints.
tips: Use max-width instead of width for responsive containers
overflow: hidden clips content - be careful with important information
overflow: auto is better than scroll (no unnecessary scrollbars)
Combine with text-overflow: ellipsis for text truncation
Use overflow: hidden to clear floats (clearfix)
Consider overflow-wrap: break-word for long words
Test scrollable areas on touch devices

lessons.title: Display Property (block, inline, inline-block)
lessons.content: The display property defines how elements generate boxes. Block elements take full width and start on new lines (div, p, h1). Inline elements flow with text and don't accept width/height (span, a). Inline-block combines both - flows inline but accepts dimensions. Display: none removes elements completely. Understanding display is crucial for layouts.

examples.description: Different display property values and their behaviors

quiz.question: Which display value accepts width/height AND flows inline?
quiz.hint: It combines features of two types
quiz.explanation: inline-block elements accept width and height like block elements but flow horizontally like inline elements.

quiz.question: What's the difference between display: none and visibility: hidden?
options: display: none removes from layout, visibility: hidden keeps space
quiz.answer: display: none removes from layout, visibility: hidden keeps space
quiz.explanation: display: none completely removes the element from the document flow, while visibility: hidden makes it invisible but preserves its space.

lessons.challenge: Create a navigation menu with inline-block links, convert a list to horizontal layout using display properties, and create a toggle that shows/hides content using display: none.
tips: Block elements: div, p, h1-h6, section, article, header, footer
Inline elements: span, a, strong, em, img
Use inline-block for navigation buttons with padding
display: none is commonly used for dropdowns and modals
Inline elements ignore top/bottom margins
Use display: block on images for better control
Modern layouts often use flexbox/grid instead of inline-block

lessons.title: Visibility and Opacity
lessons.content: Visibility and opacity control element appearance differently. visibility: hidden makes elements invisible but preserves space, visibility: collapse for table elements. Opacity controls transparency (0 to 1), affecting the entire element and its children. Unlike visibility, opacity can be animated smoothly. Use cases include fade effects, overlays, and disabled state styling.

examples.description: Visibility and opacity for controlling element appearance

quiz.question: What's the range of values for opacity?
quiz.explanation: Opacity accepts values from 0 (completely transparent) to 1 (completely opaque). Values like 0.5 represent 50% opacity.

quiz.question: Can opacity be animated with transitions?
quiz.explanation: Opacity is a numeric property that can be smoothly animated using CSS transitions or animations.

lessons.challenge: Create a photo gallery where images fade in on hover using opacity and transitions. Then create a modal overlay with semi-transparent background. Compare the space taken by elements with visibility: hidden vs display: none.
tips: visibility: hidden still takes up space, display: none doesn't

Use rgba() for transparent backgrounds without affecting children
Opacity 0 elements can still receive clicks - use pointer-events: none if needed
Fade effects work well with opacity transitions
Consider accessibility - don't rely solely on opacity for important state changes
Opacity can impact performance with many semi-transparent layers

lessons.title: Box Sizing (content-box vs border-box)
lessons.content: Box-sizing controls how width and height are calculated. content-box (default) adds padding and border to specified width. border-box includes padding and border in the width, making sizing more intuitive and predictable. Most modern CSS resets apply border-box globally for easier layout math and responsive design.

examples.description: Box-sizing models and their impact on dimensions

quiz.question: Which box-sizing value is more intuitive for layouts?
quiz.explanation: border-box is more intuitive because the width you set is the final width - padding and borders don't add extra size.

quiz.question: What's the default value of box-sizing?
quiz.explanation: The default is content-box, where width only applies to content, and padding/border are added to the total size.

lessons.challenge: Create two identical boxes with same width, padding, and border - one with content-box and one with border-box. Observe the different total sizes in DevTools. Then apply border-box globally.
tips: Apply box-sizing: border-box globally in your CSS reset
border-box makes percentage-based layouts much easier
With border-box, padding doesn't break grid layouts
Include pseudo-elements in the global reset: *, *::before, *::after
border-box is essential for responsive design
Modern CSS frameworks use border-box by default
Once you use border-box, you'll never want to go back

lessons.title: Position Property (static, relative, absolute, fixed, sticky)
lessons.content: The position property controls how elements are positioned. static is default (normal flow), relative positions relative to normal position, absolute positions relative to nearest positioned ancestor, fixed positions relative to viewport, and sticky is a hybrid (relative until scroll threshold, then fixed). Positioned elements can use top, right, bottom, left properties.

examples.description: Five position values and their behaviors

quiz.question: Which position value removes an element from normal document flow?
quiz.hint: Think about which ones don't take up space
quiz.explanation: Absolute and fixed positioning remove elements from normal flow. Relative keeps the space, and static/sticky remain in flow.

quiz.question: What does sticky positioning do?
options: Acts relative until scroll threshold, then fixed
quiz.answer: Acts relative until scroll threshold, then fixed
quiz.explanation: Sticky positioning starts as relative but becomes fixed when scrolling reaches the specified threshold (e.g., top: 0).

lessons.challenge: Create a page with: a fixed header that stays at top while scrolling, an absolute-positioned badge on a relatively-positioned card, and a sticky sidebar that sticks when scrolling.
tips: Absolute positioning is relative to nearest positioned ancestor (not static)
Set parent to position: relative for absolute children to position within it
Fixed elements are removed from flow - add padding to body if needed
Sticky requires a threshold value (top, bottom, left, or right)
Use z-index with positioned elements to control stacking
Relative positioning preserves the element's space
Test sticky on different browsers - support varies

lessons.title: Z-index and Stacking Context
lessons.content: Z-index controls stacking order of positioned elements along the Z-axis (depth). Higher values appear in front. Z-index only works on positioned elements (relative, absolute, fixed, sticky). Stacking contexts are created by certain properties (positioned elements with z-index, flex/grid items, elements with opacity < 1). Understanding stacking contexts is crucial for proper layering.

examples.description: Z-index for controlling element stacking order

quiz.question: Does z-index work on static positioned elements?
quiz.explanation: Z-index only works on positioned elements (relative, absolute, fixed, sticky), not on static (default) positioned elements.

quiz.question: What creates a new stacking context?
options: Positioned elements with z-index, opacity < 1, flex/grid items
quiz.answer: Positioned elements with z-index, opacity < 1, flex/grid items
quiz.explanation: Stacking contexts are created by positioned elements with z-index, elements with opacity < 1, flex/grid items with z-index, transform, filter, and more.

lessons.challenge: Create a layered interface with: a dropdown menu that appears above content (z-index: 100), a modal overlay (z-index: 1000), and understand why a child's z-index: 99999 can't escape its parent's stacking context.
tips: Use z-index sparingly - organize layers systematically
Common scale: content (1-9), dropdowns (10-99), modals (100-999), tooltips (1000+)
Children can't escape parent's stacking context
Use DevTools 3D view to visualize stacking
Negative z-index sends elements behind their parent
transform, filter, and opacity create new stacking contexts
Document your z-index scale for team projects

lessons.title: Float and Clear
lessons.content: Float was originally for wrapping text around images. Elements can float left or right, removing them from normal flow. Clear prevents elements from being beside floated elements. Modern layouts use flexbox/grid instead, but float is still useful for text wrapping. Floated elements need clearfix or overflow: hidden on containers to contain them properly.

examples.description: Float and clear for text wrapping and legacy layouts

quiz.question: What is the modern alternative to float for layouts?
quiz.hint: Think about modern CSS layout systems
quiz.explanation: Flexbox and CSS Grid are modern layout systems that replaced float-based layouts. Float is now mainly used for text wrapping.

quiz.question: What does clear: both do?
options: Moves element below all floated elements
quiz.answer: Moves element below all floated elements
quiz.hint: Think about positioning relative to floats
quiz.explanation: clear: both forces an element to move below any preceding floated elements (both left and right floats).

tips: Use flexbox or grid for layouts - float is outdated for this purpose
Float is still perfect for wrapping text around images
Floated elements are removed from normal document flow
Always clear floats to prevent layout issues
Use clearfix hack on containers with floated children
overflow: hidden on parent also contains floats
Clear values: left, right, both, none
Avoid float for modern responsive layouts

lessons.title: Centering Elements (horizontally & vertically)
lessons.content: CSS offers multiple centering techniques depending on context. Horizontal: margin: auto for blocks, text-align: center for inline. Vertical: flexbox, grid, or absolute positioning with transform. Modern methods (flexbox/grid) are simplest. Understanding different techniques helps handle various scenarios and browser support needs.

examples.description: Multiple techniques for centering elements

quiz.question: What's the easiest modern method to center elements?
quiz.explanation: Flexbox and Grid provide the simplest, most reliable centering with just a few lines of code.

quiz.question: How does margin: auto center block elements?
options: Sets left/right margins to equal values
quiz.answer: Sets left/right margins to equal values
quiz.explanation: margin: auto sets left and right margins to equal values, centering the block element within its container.

tips: Use margin: auto for horizontal centering of block elements
text-align: center works for inline and text elements
Flexbox: justify-content centers horizontally, align-items centers vertically
Grid: place-items is a shorthand for centering on both axes
Absolute positioning with transform is useful for overlays/modals

lessons.title: Inline vs Block-level Elements
lessons.content: HTML elements are categorized as block-level or inline by default. Block-level elements (div, p, h1-h6, section) start on new lines and take full width available. Inline elements (span, a, strong, em) flow within text and only take necessary width. Understanding this distinction is crucial for proper layout control and choosing when to change display properties.

examples.description: Understanding and controlling block vs inline behavior

quiz.question: Which elements are block-level by default?
quiz.hint: Think about elements that start on new lines
quiz.explanation: Block-level elements include structural elements like div, p, headings, section, article, header, footer, and nav.

quiz.question: Can inline elements have width and height?
quiz.hint: Inline elements only take space they need
quiz.explanation: Inline elements ignore width and height properties because they flow with text content and only occupy the space their content requires.

Use inline-block for navigation items that need padding and dimensions

Modern layouts use flexbox/grid instead of manipulating display values

lessons.title: What is Flexbox and Why Use It
lessons.content: Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a one-dimensional layout system designed for distributing space and aligning items within a container. It solves common CSS problems: vertical centering, equal-height columns, and flexible space distribution. Flexbox is perfect for navigation bars, card layouts, and component-level layouts. It's one-dimensional (row OR column), while Grid is two-dimensional.

examples.description: Introduction to Flexbox and its advantages

quiz.question: Is Flexbox one-dimensional or two-dimensional?
quiz.explanation: Flexbox is one-dimensional, working with either rows or columns at a time. CSS Grid is two-dimensional, handling rows and columns simultaneously.

quiz.question: What property creates a flex container?
quiz.explanation: Setting display: flex on an element makes it a flex container, and its direct children become flex items.

lessons.challenge: Convert a traditional layout to Flexbox. Create a container with three items and use display: flex to automatically create equal-height columns. Compare the code simplicity to older float-based methods.
tips: Flexbox revolutionized CSS layouts - learn it well
Use Flexbox for component-level layouts (navbars, cards, buttons)
Use Grid for page-level layouts
Flexbox automatically creates equal-height items
Great browser support - safe to use in all modern projects
Flexbox works on direct children only (not grandchildren)
Perfect for responsive layouts with flex-wrap
Solves the 'vertical centering' problem elegantly

lessons.title: Main Axis & Cross Axis
lessons.content: Flexbox operates on two axes: the main axis (direction of flex-direction) and cross axis (perpendicular to main). flex-direction: row makes main axis horizontal, flex-direction: column makes it vertical. justify-content aligns along main axis, align-items aligns along cross axis. Understanding these axes is fundamental to mastering Flexbox positioning.

examples.description: Understanding Flexbox main and cross axes

quiz.question: With flex-direction: row, which property controls horizontal alignment?
quiz.explanation: justify-content aligns items along the main axis. With flex-direction: row, the main axis is horizontal, so justify-content controls horizontal alignment.

quiz.question: What happens to axes when flex-direction changes to column?
options: Main axis becomes vertical, cross axis becomes horizontal
quiz.answer: Main axis becomes vertical, cross axis becomes horizontal
quiz.explanation: When flex-direction is column, the main axis runs vertically (top to bottom) and the cross axis runs horizontally (left to right).

lessons.challenge: Create four containers with different flex-directions (row, row-reverse, column, column-reverse). Add colored items and observe how justify-content and align-items behave differently in each direction.

justify-content ALWAYS works on main axis
align-items ALWAYS works on cross axis
Default flex-direction is row (horizontal main axis)
When confused, remember: justify = main, align = cross
Use DevTools to visualize flex containers and axes
row-reverse and column-reverse flip the direction but keep the same axes
Understanding axes is key to mastering Flexbox

lessons.title: Flex Container Properties (justify-content, align-items, flex-wrap)
lessons.content: Flex container properties control how items are distributed and aligned. justify-content aligns along main axis (flex-start, center, space-between, space-around, space-evenly). align-items aligns along cross axis (stretch, flex-start, center, flex-end, baseline). flex-wrap allows items to wrap to new lines. align-content controls spacing between wrapped lines.

quiz.question: What's the difference between space-between and space-around?
options: space-between: edge items touch edges, space-around: equal space around all
quiz.answer: space-between: edge items touch edges, space-around: equal space around all
quiz.explanation: space-between places first and last items at container edges with equal space between. space-around gives each item equal space on both sides, creating half-space at edges.

quiz.question: What does align-items: stretch do?
options: Makes items fill container's cross-axis dimension
quiz.answer: Makes items fill container's cross-axis dimension
quiz.explanation: align-items: stretch (default) makes flex items stretch to fill the container's height (in row direction) or width (in column direction).

tips: space-evenly is most commonly used for equal distribution
align-items: stretch is default - items fill container height
Use flex-wrap: wrap for responsive layouts
align-content only works with wrapped multi-line containers
gap property adds spacing between items (modern alternative to margins)
justify-content works on main axis, align-items on cross axis
Combine properties for complex layouts: justify-content: center + align-items: center
Use DevTools Flexbox inspector to visualize alignment

lessons.title: Flex Item Properties (flex-grow, flex-shrink, flex-basis, align-self)
lessons.content: Flex item properties control individual item behavior. flex-grow defines how much an item grows relative to others (default 0). flex-shrink controls shrinking when space is limited (default 1). flex-basis sets initial size before growing/shrinking. align-self overrides container's align-items for individual items. The flex shorthand combines grow, shrink, and basis.

quiz.explanation: flex: 1 is shorthand for flex: 1 1 0, meaning the item can grow, can shrink, and starts with 0 basis (content size).

quiz.question: How do you create a fixed-size flex item that doesn't grow or shrink?
quiz.explanation: flex: 0 0 200px sets grow=0 (won't grow), shrink=0 (won't shrink), basis=200px (fixed size).

flex: 0 0 200px creates fixed-size items
flex-grow: 0 (default) means item won't grow
flex-shrink: 1 (default) allows items to shrink
flex-basis can be px, %, or auto

align-self overrides align-items for specific items

lessons.title: Real Flexbox Layout Examples (Navbar, Cards)
lessons.content: Practical Flexbox applications solve real-world layout challenges. Navigation bars use space-between for logo and links alignment. Card grids use flex-wrap for responsive layouts. Holy grail layouts combine Flexbox with flex-direction. Form layouts use Flexbox for input alignment. These patterns are fundamental to modern web development.

lessons.title: Introduction to CSS Grid
lessons.content: CSS Grid is a two-dimensional layout system for creating complex web layouts with rows and columns simultaneously. Unlike Flexbox (one-dimensional), Grid excels at page-level layouts, image galleries, and dashboard designs. Grid containers define the grid structure, and grid items are automatically placed or explicitly positioned. Grid is the most powerful CSS layout system and pairs perfectly with Flexbox.

examples.description: Introduction to CSS Grid two-dimensional layouts

quiz.question: What's the main difference between Flexbox and Grid?
options: Grid is two-dimensional, Flexbox is one-dimensional
quiz.answer: Grid is two-dimensional, Flexbox is one-dimensional
quiz.explanation: Grid handles both rows and columns simultaneously (two-dimensional), while Flexbox handles either rows or columns at a time (one-dimensional).

quiz.question: What does 'fr' unit mean in Grid?
quiz.explanation: The 'fr' unit represents a fraction of the available space in the grid container, allowing flexible and proportional sizing.

lessons.title: Defining Rows and Columns
lessons.content: Grid tracks (rows and columns) are defined with grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows. Values can be fixed (px), flexible (fr), percentages, or auto. The repeat() function creates multiple tracks. minmax() sets minimum and maximum sizes. auto-fill and auto-fit create responsive grids. Understanding track sizing is crucial for creating flexible and responsive grid layouts.

quiz.explanation: auto-fill creates as many columns as fit (even empty ones), while auto-fit creates columns and expands items to fill available space.

quiz.question: What does minmax(200px, 1fr) do?

Use minmax() to set constraints on flexible columns
grid-auto-rows sets height for automatically created rows
auto keyword makes tracks size to content

lessons.title: Grid Areas and Gap
lessons.content: Grid areas provide a semantic way to define layouts using named regions. grid-template-areas creates a visual representation of the layout. Items are placed using grid-area property. The gap property (grid-gap in older syntax) adds spacing between grid items. This approach makes complex layouts readable and maintainable, perfect for page-level structures.

examples.description: Grid areas for semantic layouts and gap for spacing

quiz.question: What does a dot (.) represent in grid-template-areas?
quiz.explanation: A dot (.) in grid-template-areas represents an empty cell, allowing you to create layouts with intentional gaps.

quiz.question: Can gap property have different values for rows and columns?
quiz.explanation: You can use row-gap and column-gap separately, or gap: [row] [column] shorthand, to set different spacing for rows and columns.

Use dots (.) for empty cells

lessons.title: Grid Item Alignment and Positioning
lessons.content: Grid items can be aligned within their cells using justify-items (horizontal), align-items (vertical), and place-items (both). Individual items use justify-self, align-self, and place-self. Items can span multiple rows/columns using grid-column and grid-row. Explicit placement uses line numbers or span keyword. This control enables precise positioning within the grid structure.

quiz.question: What's the difference between grid-column: span 2 and grid-column: 1 / 3?
options: span 2 spans 2 columns from auto position, 1/3 spans specific lines

lessons.title: CSS Transitions (ease, linear, delay)
lessons.content: CSS transitions smoothly animate property changes between states. The transition property specifies which properties to animate, duration, timing function (ease, linear, ease-in, ease-out), and delay. Transitions trigger on state changes like :hover, :focus, or JavaScript class changes. They're perfect for hover effects, button interactions, and simple animations without keyframes.

examples.description: CSS transitions for smooth property changes

quiz.question: What's the correct order of transition values?
quiz.explanation: The order is: property (what to animate), duration (how long), timing-function (how it moves), delay (when to start).

quiz.question: Should you use transition: all in production?
options: No, it's better to specify exact properties
quiz.answer: No, it's better to specify exact properties
quiz.explanation: transition: all can cause performance issues and unexpected animations. It's better to specify exact properties for control and performance.

lessons.title: CSS Keyframe Animations
lessons.content: Keyframe animations create complex, multi-step animations using @keyframes rule. Define animation states at percentages (0%, 50%, 100%) or from/to keywords. Apply animations with animation property, specifying name, duration, timing, delay, iteration-count, direction, and fill-mode. Keyframes enable loading spinners, entrance effects, and continuous animations beyond simple transitions.

lessons.title: Transform Property (scale, rotate, translate, skew)
lessons.content: The transform property applies 2D and 3D transformations without affecting document flow. Common functions include scale() for sizing, rotate() for rotation, translate() for movement, and skew() for distortion. Transforms can be combined and are hardware-accelerated for smooth performance. Transform-origin controls the pivot point. Transforms are essential for modern animations and interactive effects.

options: They're applied in order from left to right
quiz.answer: They're applied in order from left to right
quiz.explanation: Transforms are applied in the order written. transform: scale(2) rotate(45deg) is different from rotate(45deg) scale(2) - order matters!

quiz.question: What does transform-origin control?
quiz.explanation: transform-origin sets the point around which transformations (especially rotation) occur. Default is center, but can be set to any position.

lessons.title: Creating Hover Animations and Microinteractions
lessons.content: Microinteractions are subtle animations that provide feedback and enhance user experience. Hover effects, button ripples, loading states, and focus indicators are common microinteractions. Combine transitions, transforms, and pseudo-classes to create engaging interfaces. Good microinteractions are subtle, purposeful, and fast (200-400ms). They guide users, confirm actions, and make interfaces feel responsive and polished.

quiz.question: What's the ideal duration for microinteractions?
quiz.explanation: Microinteractions should be fast enough to not slow down interaction (200-400ms) but slow enough to be perceived and provide feedback.

quiz.answer: Prevents content from showing outside container

lessons.title: Media Queries and Breakpoints
lessons.content: Media queries apply styles based on device characteristics like screen width, height, orientation, and resolution. Breakpoints define where layouts change for different screen sizes. Common breakpoints: 576px (mobile), 768px (tablet), 992px (desktop), 1200px (large desktop). Use min-width (mobile-first) or max-width (desktop-first). Media queries are essential for responsive web design.

quiz.answer: min-width: styles apply at width and above, max-width: at width and below
quiz.explanation: min-width applies styles from the specified width upward (mobile-first), while max-width applies from the specified width downward (desktop-first).

quiz.question: Which approach is recommended: mobile-first or desktop-first?
quiz.explanation: Mobile-first (min-width) is recommended as it follows progressive enhancement, starting with essential mobile styles and adding complexity for larger screens.

lessons.content: Mobile-first starts with mobile styles and progressively enhances for larger screens using min-width media queries. Desktop-first starts with desktop styles and scales down using max-width. lessons.title: CSS Variables (Custom Properties)
lessons.content: CSS Variables store reusable values using --property-name syntax and access with var(). Define in :root for global scope or within selectors for local scope. Variables cascade, inherit, can be updated with JavaScript, and are perfect for theming, consistency, and reducing repetition.

quiz.hint: Highest level in the document tree
quiz.explanation: :root represents the document root and is the conventional place to define global CSS variables for use throughout the stylesheet.

quiz.explanation: CSS variables can be updated with JavaScript using element.style.setProperty('--variable', 'value'), making them perfect for dynamic theming.

lessons.title: CSS Functions (calc(), clamp(), min(), max())
lessons.content: CSS functions perform calculations and dynamic sizing. calc() does mathematical operations, clamp() sets min/preferred/max values, min() returns smallest value, max() returns largest. These functions create responsive, maintainable designs without media queries. They're essential for fluid typography, flexible spacing, and adaptive layouts.

quiz.explanation: calc() can mix different units (%, px, rem, vw, etc.), allowing calculations like calc(100% - 20px) or calc(50vw + 2rem).
